since_last_update: US demand tone softened: December retail sales headline and core printed 0.0% m/m vs +0.4% expected, reinforcing a near-term growth downshift narrative and raising sensitivity to any follow-through in labor data (LOCAL).

Rates vs growth cross-currents intensified: softer consumption data should mechanically support a rates-bid/real-yield down impulse (supportive for duration assets) while simultaneously increasing “growth scare” risk for cyclicals/small caps (inference from retail sales miss).

Fed-speak adds optionality risk: Bostic’s “caution on choppy jobs” framing keeps market attention on labor prints as the arbiter for the next policy reprice, increasing odds of intraday whipsaw around jobs/inflation releases (LOCAL; driver confirmation from broader tape remains mixed).
UK political noise re-entered as a second-order global risk-premium input (GBP/UK assets first, spillover to global risk only if it escalates) (Reuters).
today_focus: Dominant driver check (US equities/futures): macro-data sequencing and rates impulse—markets are calibrating to the consumption downshift from retail sales while looking ahead to the high-impact US labor cluster (Reuters, Barron's, Investopedia).

Equity index behavior likely to be “rates-help vs growth-hurt”: if yields fall on weaker data, NQ can be cushioned via duration mechanics, but ES/RTY may lag if the tape interprets the miss as real economy slowdown rather than disinflation (inference).

Gold focus: sensitive to USD/real-yield regime; recent coverage emphasizes dollar weakness and confidence/independence narratives as key supports, but positioning/volatility implies outsized two-way risk on any USD rebound or hawkish repricing (MarketWatch, Reuters).

Earnings microstructure is additive, not primary: large single-name moves (e.g., consumer staples/tech) can tug index futures at the margin, but the macro calendar (jobs + CPI) is the higher-order driver (AP, Barron's, Reuters).

dominant_driver.fact: Macro calendar / rates repricing is the dominant plausible driver into the US session, with retail sales surprise feeding a growth-vs-rates tug-of-war; earnings are secondary.
dominant_driver.inference: Base case is a higher beta of ES/NQ and gold to real-yield moves than to single-name earnings, until the labor and CPI prints resolve the 'soft growth vs sticky inflation' question.

rates_path.fact: Markets are focused on whether weak activity data validates easing expectations versus Fed-caution messaging that could slow that repricing.
rates_path.inference: Front-end pricing likely to remain jumpy: a weak jobs print would reinforce cuts; a firm jobs/earnings print could snap yields higher and pressure duration (especially NQ, gold).

usd_real_yields_gold.fact: Recent reporting frames gold as being supported by dollar weakness and confidence/political independence narratives; Reuters also highlighted episodes where USD strength + real-yield repricing triggered sharp precious-metals drawdowns.
usd_real_yields_gold.inference: Gold is pricing an elevated non-macro premium (confidence/geopolitical/fiscal) that can persist, but is vulnerable to abrupt liquidation on USD rebounds or hawkish surprises.

equity_factor_map.fact: Tape has been alternating between tech-led rebounds and de-risking episodes tied to macro and rates shifts (Reuters).
equity_factor_map.inference: Concentration risk remains: NQ sensitivity to discount-rate shocks stays high; ES breadth/rotation can mask index-level calm while factor volatility rises.

risk_register.risk: Rates whipsaw around the US labor + CPI cluster (Feb 11 jobs; Feb 13 CPI): real-yield impulse can flip ES/NQ and drive gold convexity (especially if data conflict).
Growth-scare repricing: retail sales miss becomes a broader consumer slowdown narrative, weighing ES cyclicals/RTY even if yields fall (bad-good data paradox).
Gold positioning/liquidity air-pocket: elevated recent volatility increases probability of disorderly moves on USD spikes, real-yield jumps, or headline shocks.
Fed communication risk: speaker tone (Logan/Hammack/Bowman etc.) could push back on easing pricing after weak activity data, triggering rate back-up and duration drawdown.
Second-order political risk spillover (UK leadership noise): mostly GBP/gilts risk, but can contaminate global risk sentiment if it escalates into policy/fiscal uncertainty.

event_warnings: Tue 2026-02-10: US Business Inventories (15:00 UTC) is low impact but can be used to reinforce/deny the slowdown narrative if retail-sales is already in focus.
Tue 2026-02-10: Fed speakers (Hammack 17:00 UTC; Logan 18:00 UTC) — watch for any pushback on easing expectations after weak retail sales (risk: yield snapback).
Wed 2026-02-11 13:30 UTC: US jobs cluster (NFP, unemployment rate, avg hourly earnings) — primary binary catalyst for rates and NQ/ES factor leadership.
Wed 2026-02-11: US 10y auction (18:01 UTC) — tail risk if demand is weak into a data-heavy week (can steepen/raise term premium).
Thu 2026-02-12 13:30 UTC: Initial claims — can amplify the post-NFP narrative if it confirms weakening or re-accelerating labor conditions.
Fri 2026-02-13 13:30 UTC: US CPI (headline/core) — highest-impact inflation catalyst; gold and NQ likely to react via real yields and USD.
